Asclepius 2012-05-27T12:28:36-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/ Paul Kulyk paul.kulyk@gmail.com edus2 website updates 2012-04-28T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/2012/04/28/vanity-header-website-updates <p>I have been furiously updating <a href="http://www.edus2.com">edus2</a> in anticipation of the trip to the SAEM AGM in Chicago. A new twitter account <a href="http://www.twitter.com/edus2sim">edus2sim</a> has been created specifically for edus2 updates. The blog and website format have been heavily updated.</p> <p>In addition I have started dragging in some of the changes to that site over to this one as well. Hopefully I can start creating a nice resume with all these things for the upcoming CaRMS showdown.</p> edus2 in rural BC - the first working clone 2012-02-14T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/2012/02/14/edus2-hits-rural-bc <p><a href="http://www.edus2.com">edus2</a> collaboration strikes again!</p> <p>Jel Coward, an MD with a keen interest in open source projects, and his team have created their own working edus2 machine. This is the first confirmed replication of the project and a significant milestone for is.</p> <p>With this we found a few bugs. He installed it on an earlier version of Ubuntu and had to tweak a few things to work. None-the-less the system is up and running.</p> <p>These changes will be integrated into the git repository under a separate branch in case anyone else is interested in running on an older version of Ubuntu.</p> <p>All the hiccups encountered could go away if we had someone with a bit of free time and an interest in the project could package the program for Ubuntu.</p> <p>Outstanding <a href="https://github.com/asclepius/edus2/issues">issues</a></p> <ul> <li>Probe design</li> <li>Ubuntu packages</li> <li>Automatic card setup software</li> </ul> <p>Anyone interested please contact me, or just go the <a href="http://www.edus2.com">edus2</a> and get started by forking the project.</p> edus2 wiki updates, probe design 2012-02-01T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/2012/02/01/edus2-wiki-and-hardware <p>The <a href="https://github.com/asclepius/edus2/wiki" title="github: edus2 wiki">edus2 wiki</a> underwent a lot of changes over the weekend. A set of step-by-step instructions has been added to the <a href="https://github.com/asclepius/edus2/wiki/Installation">Installation</a> page. Anyone that has some experience with the command line should have no problem with it.</p> <p>The weak link with the system right now is making a nice-looking probe. My colleague/friend/cousin Erik Kulyk has decided to help out with the project and is looking in to a professionally fabricated probe.</p> <p>The outstanding <a href="https://github.com/asclepius/edus2/issues">Issues</a> now include:</p> <ul> <li>Probe design</li> <li>Automation of the initial setup process</li> <li>Ubuntu package for quick installation</li> </ul> edus2 website, auto-scan adder, and live-cd 2012-01-11T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/ultrasound/edus/edus2/rfid/2012/01/11/edus2-website <p>The <a href="http://www.edus2.com">edus2 website</a> has come a long way. The basic format is now intact and all that remains are some touch ups and adding photos and video demonstration of the system.</p> <p>The next step is to finish the system for automatically prompting the user to scan a tag for each video in a given folder. Once this is done the automation process will make setup a lot more user friendly.</p> <p>After the quick-setup feature is finished the whole thing will be bundled into a linux distribution that will simply boot to the running program. Once this is put together the user can simply download and burn the iso, insert the disk, and install the system. It removes the hassle of adding python packages and setting up software. The laptop will most likely be dedicated to the lab so no issues with dual booting will be required.</p> <p>If anyone want to get involved with an open source project and package this up for Ubuntu that would be appreciated as well!</p> EDUS2 and Thermomulator work 2011-12-17T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/ultrasound/edus/edus2/thermomulator/rfid/2011/12/17/edus2-and-thermomulator <p>Over the past few days I&rsquo;ve completed some of the pending work on the <a href="http://asclepius.github.com/edus2">EDUS2 project.</a> The prototype has been working for sometime, but now the code has been uploaded to github and a basic description has been submitted. A full description with images, instructions for building, material, and a usage video will follow shortly.</p> <p>The thermomulator code has been completed and <a href="http://asclepius.github.com/Thermomulator">uploaded.</a> It&rsquo;s pretty basic. The trickier part is squeezing it into a box that looks like a thermometer, this is almost done just waiting for the drill to recharge to finish putting some holes in the cases to connect the sensors. Maybe a drill press should be added to the Christmas list? </p> Bash Hack of the Week - METAR 2011-11-18T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/bash/metar/taf/weather/2011/11/18/bash-hack-1 <p>I&rsquo;ve got a ~/bin full of cheap bash hacks I have come up with over the years and I thought this would be a good forum to start sharing them. Some of the more complex ones I might start commiting to github. </p> <p>I cycle to and from work/school a lot and I like to know what the prairie winds are going to be doing. If you know how to read metar/taf aviation weather reports it can be handy to have this information quickly available at the command line, or wrapped into a website, or in your bash prompt, etc.</p> <p>Here&rsquo;s a simple script to get metar data for a given site:</p> <pre><code>#!/bin/bash # Usage &lt;this_file&gt; &lt;4 letter airport station id&gt; STATION=echo $1 | tr &lsquo;[a-z]&rsquo; &lsquo;[A-Z]&rsquo; TAF_REPO=&ldquo;http://weather.noaa.gov/pub/data/forecasts/taf/stations/&rdquo; METAR_REPO=&ldquo;http://weather.noaa.gov/pub/data/observations/metar/stations/&rdquo; REPO=$METAR_REPO curl -s ${REPO}${STATION}.TXT | sed 1d </code></pre> <p>Copy this into a file called metar:</p> <pre><code>cd ~/bin # or mkdir ~/bin &amp;&amp; cd ~/bin cat &gt; metar #paste and finish with ctrl-D </code></pre> <p>Make it executable:</p> <pre><code>chmod +x metar </code></pre> <p>Run it:</p> <pre><code>./metar cyhz </code></pre> <p>That should spit out something like:</p> <pre><code>CYHZ 181500Z 28014G25KT 15SM SCT028 02/M02 A2984 RMK SC3 SLP108 </code></pre> <p>You can make another file called taf, copy the code from metar into and change the REPO line. This will give you a forecast.</p> Simulation Thermometer Begins 2011-11-16T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/2011/11/16/thermometer <p>I&rsquo;m creating a simple simulated digital thermometer for use in medical simulation labs. To get things going fast I&rsquo;m planning on just using an Arduino, a potentiometer, and a 7 segment led array.</p> <p>The instructor will set the temperature using the potentiometer and the student will get the result displayed back when they check the manequins temperature. Blinking lights and a beeper will make it act more like a real hospital thermometer.</p> <p>Parts are in! Once exams are over I estimated a half-day of hacking should get it done.</p> <p>Project page with full description and source code to follow.</p> First Post 2011-11-12T00:00:00-06:00 http://asclepius.github.com/2011/11/12/first-post <p>Hello github.</p> <p>This is my first post. I&rsquo;m starting a few small open source projects and thought I would try github for hosting the source code and design plans.</p>
